snippet: So far, there are no reported episodes of violence committed with such weapons, but police officials worry it is just a matter of time.
abstract: Law enforcement agencies across Europe are on alert over the proliferation of gun-making software that is easily found on the Internet and can be used to make a weapon on a consumer-grade 3-D printer; no episodes of violence committed with such weapons have been reported, but police warn it is only a matter of time.

byline.contributor: Christina Hess contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: So far, there are no reported episodes of violence committed with such weapons, but police officials worry it is just a matter of time.

headline.main: Authorities Worry 3-D Printers May Undermine Europe’s Gun Laws
headline.print_headline: Authorities Worry 3-D Printers May Undermine Europe’s Gun Laws
